Eightieth session 
Fifth Committee 
Agenda item 136 
Proposed programme budget for 2026 
 
 
 
Draft resolution submitted by the Chair of the Committee following 
informal consultations 
 
 
Questions relating to the proposed programme budget for 2026 
 
 
 
The General Assembly, 
 
Reaffirming its resolutions 41/213 of 19 December 1986, 42/211 of 
21 December 1987, 45/248 B, section VI, of 21 December 1990, 55/231 of 
23 December 2000, 56/253 of 24 December 2001, 58/269 and 58/270 of 23 December 
2003, 59/276, section XI, of 23 December 2004, 60/283 of 7 July 2006, 61/263 of 
4 April 2007, 62/236 of 22 December 2007, 63/262 of 24 December 2008, 64/243 of 
24 December 2009, 65/259 of 24 December 2010, 66/246 of 24 December 2011, 
68/246 of 27 December 2013, 70/247 of 23 December 2015, 72/261 and 72/266 A of 
24 December 2017, 72/266 B of 5 July 2018, 73/281 of 22 December 2018, 74/262 
of 27 December 2019, 75/252 of 31 December 2020, 76/245 of 24 December 2021, 
76/271 of 29 June 2022, 77/262 and 77/267 of 30 December 2022, 77/253 B of 
30 June 2023, 78/242 A, 78/252, 78/253 and 78/257 of 22 December 2023, 79/245 A, 
79/257 and 79/258 A of 24 December 2024 and 79/258 B of 11 April 2025, 
 
Reaffirming also the respective mandates of the Committee for Programme and 
Coordination and the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary 
Questions in the consideration of the proposed programme budget, 
 
Reaffirming further the role of the General Assembly, through the Fifth 
Committee, in carrying out a thorough analysis and approval of posts and financial 
resources, as well as of human resources policies, 
 
Having considered the reports of the Secretary-General on the proposed 
programme budget for 2026, 1  on the revised estimates relating to the proposed 
programme budget for 2026 and the support account for peacekeeping operations for 
the 2025/26 period,2 on the implementation of projects financed from the Development 
Account: fourteenth progress report,3 on strengthening the effectiveness and impact of

the support account for peacekeeping operations for the 2025/26 period 6 and the related 
reports of the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions, 7 
 
Having also considered the notes by the Secretary-General drawing attention to the 
reports of the Joint Inspection Unit,8 as well as the comments of the Secretary-General 
and of the United Nations System Chief Executive Board for Coordination thereon, 9 
 
1. 
Reaffirms rule 153 of its rules of procedure; 
 
2. 
Also reaffirms the Regulations and Rules Governing Programme Planning, 
the Programme Aspects of the Budget, the Monitoring of Implementation and the 
Methods of Evaluation;10 
 
3. 
Further reaffirms the Financial Regulations and Rules of the United 
Nations;11 
 
4. 
Reaffirms its resolution 80/___ of ______________ 2025; 
 
5. 
Endorses the conclusions and recommendations contained in the reports 
of the Advisory Committee of Administrative and Budgetary Questions, subject to the 
provisions of the present resolution; 
 
6. 
Reaffirms that the Fifth Committee is the appropriate Main Committee of 
the General Assembly entrusted with responsibilities for administrative and budgetary 
matters, and reaffirms the role of the Fifth Committee in carrying out a thorough 
analysis and approving human and financial resources and policies, with a view to 
ensuring full, effective and efficient implementation of all mandated programmes and 
activities and the implementation of policies in this regard; 
 
7. 
Stresses that finance serves as a foundation of and an important element 
underpinning United Nations governance; 
 
8. 
Recalls its resolution 79/318 of 18 July 2025 on the UN80 Initiative, and 
welcomes the efforts of the Secretary-General to strengthen the United Nations through 
structural and programmatic realignment to address duplication, reduce overlap, 
enhance transparency, strengthen mandate delivery and make the Organization more 
efficient, effective, impactful and fit for purpose for the people it serves; 
 
9. 
Notes the interconnected nature of the three workstreams of the UN80 
Initiative, which seek operational efficiencies and improvements, review of mandate 
implementation and structural and programmatic realignment of the Organization, 
stresses in this regard the importance of ensuring close coordination and coherence 
among the three workstreams so that their outcomes continue to be ambitious and 
mutually reinforcing and contribute to a comprehensive, accountable, transparent and

integrated reform process, and looks forward to tangible outcomes and proposals 
presented to Member States in 2026 and 2027; 
 
10. 
Recalls paragraphs 4, 6 and 16 of the report of the Advisory Committee, 12 
stresses that the UN80 Initiative requires going beyond a one-time reform exercise to 
also incorporate continuous efforts to ensure long-term effective and efficient mandate 
delivery across all three pillars of the work of the United Nations, and requests the 
Secretary-General to pursue synergies to achieve greater efficiency in the management 
of resources and to report on the outcome of such efforts in his next budget submission; 
 
11. 
Requests the Secretary-General to continue to follow the legislative 
framework, as agreed by Member States, and the established procedural steps 
applicable to proposals presented as part of the UN80 Initiative; 
 
12. Recognizes the need for indicators for providing quantifiable information 
on entities’ efforts to drive a culture of efficiency and cost-effectiveness, and requests 
the Secretary-General to include, in future proposed programme budgets, quantitative 
indicators on entities’ cost efficiency measures and an analysis of their effectiveness; 
 
13. Also recognizes the need to analyse the impact, costs and benefits of the 
Secretary-General’s reform efforts, and requests the Secretary-General to include, in 
his future proposed programme budgets, the impact of changes on mandate 
implementation and performance; 
 
14. Recalls paragraph 28 of its resolution 79/257, and requests the Secretary-
General to continue applying zero-based budgeting in order to end the high degree of 
automaticity in future budget preparation and match the proposed requirements with 
programmes whose mandates are still valid; 
 
15. 
Requests the Secretary-General to maintain the momentum of the UN80 
Initiative, continue to identify efficiencies in how each Secretariat entity can enhance the 
overall effectiveness of the Organization and strengthen budget discipline, by absorbing 
the resource implications of new mandates within existing resources, where appropriate; 
 
16. Recalls paragraph 44 of the report of the Advisory Committee, 13 
emphasizes the importance of the rejuvenation of the Secretariat, requests the 
Secretary-General to include proposals for programmatic realignments and structural 
changes, including with the aim to reduce or reclassify the overall number of Under-
Secretary-General, Assistant Secretary-General, D-2 and D-1 posts markedly in the 
context of the UN80 Initiative, in the proposed programme budget for 2028; 
 
17. Also recalls paragraph 29 of the report of the Advisory Committee, 14 
reaffirms paragraphs 19 and 64 of its resolution 79/257, stresses that the 
implementation of the UN80 Initiative should be supported by a coordinated approach 
to organizational transformation across the various entities of the Organization, and 
underscores that internal control and accountability are central principles of 
management reform, and the importance of strengthening a culture of accountability 
through the relevant internal oversight and control mechanisms to ensure effective, 
accountable and transparent delivery of reforms; 
 
18. Requests the Secretary-General to ensure effective and efficient utilization 
of available existing resources and programme delivery by senior managers and 
programme managers, including through clearly defined results-based performance 
indicators and benchmarks that provide feedback to senior managers and programme 
managers and drive improvements on the delivery of mandates;

19. 
Recalls paragraph 74 of the report of the Advisory Committee,15 encourages 
continued work on improving administrative and operational effectiveness of the 
Secretariat, including in coordination with other United Nations system entities, and 
looks forward to receiving proposals on restructuring Secretariat operations; 
 
20. Welcomes the Secretary-General’s proposals on the consolidation and 
streamlining of support services and structures across the Secretariat, encourages the 
implementation of such measures to achieve both immediate and long-term financial 
savings and to foster a more integrated flexible and resilient approach to service 
delivery, and looks forward to additional proposals from the next phase of work on 
the proposed programme budget for 2027, while taking into account the different 
sizes, complexities and operational environments of Secretariat entities; 
 
21. 
Recalls paragraph 71 of the report of the Advisory Committee,16 and requests 
the Secretary-General to operate under a common approach to scalability for 
transactional services, including those provided under common administrative 
platforms, that aligns service demand and related staffing requirements with workload 
indicators, including variables related to productivity and differences in funding sources; 
 
22. Requests the Secretary-General to continue his efforts to achieve 
transparency and improve the accuracy, comprehensiveness and analysability of the 
budgetary data, refine the presentation of the proposed programme budget, and to 
provide complete, clear, comparable and transparent financial data to the General 
Assembly, including both gross and net requirements, and preliminary cost estimates 
that are available for the respective year at the time of publication of the proposed 
programme budget, such as, inter alia, total construction and total recosting estimates, 
so as to give clarity on the real growth of the budget request to enable Member States 
to make well-informed decisions; 
 
23. Recalls paragraph 23 of its resolution 79/257, and requests the Secretary-
General to continue his efforts to provide accurate, adequate and dynamic information 
related to administrative, budgetary and human resources matters to Member States 
through the Umoja portal and to continue to enhance Member States’ access to the 
Umoja system; 
 
24. Requests the Secretary-General to update the search and retrieval tools 
within the e-deleGATE platform to enable Member States to search using keywords 
across documents and enhance efforts to preserve institutional knowledge; 
 
25. Also requests the Secretary-General to consider and implement options to 
improve the ease of access to e-deleGATE through multi-factor authentication for 
delegates; 
 
26. 
Recalls paragraph 80 of the report of the Advisory Committee,17 notes that 
proposals for relocations should ensure better and more integrated mandate delivery 
across all aspects of the Organization’s work and contribute to its strategic objectives, 
while eliminating duplication and saving costs, and emphasizes that all current and 
future relocation proposals shall be based on functional assessments, including 
proximity to operations and field presence, demonstrating where work can be delivered 
most cost-efficiently, and that these assessments shall be provided to Member States; 
 
27. Also recalls paragraph 13 of the report of the Advisory Committee, 18 
further recalls that multilingualism is a core and fundamental value of the

Organization, and emphasizes the critical importance of the UN80 Initiative being 
leveraged to guarantee its full, effective and efficient implementation; 
 
28. Further recalls paragraph VII.22 of the report of the Advisory Committee, 19 
and requests the Secretary-General to ensure the equal and adequate treatment of all 
six official languages and to provide an update thereon in his next budget submission; 
 
29. Recalls paragraph I.70 of the report of the Advisory Committee, 20 notes 
current challenges in ensuring full and uninterrupted conference management because 
of the liquidity situation of the Organization, and encourages the Secretary-General 
to make additional efforts to provide conference management to meetings contained 
in the calendar of conferences of the United Nations for 2026 and approved by the 
General Assembly; 
 
30. Urges all Member States to fulfil their financial obligations as set out in 
the Charter of the United Nations on time, in full and without conditions; 
 
31. Requests the Secretary-General to make every effort to facilitate Member 
States’ payments of their contributions, including in cases when there are 
circumstances beyond their control in making payments; 
 
32. Also requests the Secretary-General to meaningfully engage with Member 
States in the budget preparation process with respect to the implementation of the 
recent General Assembly resolutions on budgetary matters and the presentation 
format of the proposed programme budget; 
 
33. Stresses that results-based budgeting and results-based management are 
mutually supportive management tools and that improved implementation of results-
based budgeting enhances both management and accountability in the Secretariat, and 
encourages the Secretary-General to continue his efforts to improve the presentation 
of the proposed programme budget and ensure that resources are clearly linked to a 
results-based budgeting framework and reflect existing mandates and the measures to 
achieve them; 
 
34. Recalls paragraph 28 of its resolution 79/257, underscores that long-term 
reform can only be achieved through building a culture of efficiency, cost-
effectiveness and transparency throughout the Secretariat, and requests the Secretary-
General to continue to conduct and strengthen spending reviews; 
 
35. 
Also recalls paragraph 10 of annex I to its resolution 41/213 and paragraph 29 
of its resolution 79/257, reiterates the need for a comprehensive solution to the 
problem of additional expenditures derived from inflation and currency fluctuation, 
decides not to recost the proposed programme budget as from 2027, pending the 
comprehensive review of the annual programme budget cycle at the eighty-third 
session; 
 
36. 
Reaffirms the terms of financial regulation 2.10 and rule 153 of its rules of 
procedure, urges the Secretary-General to ensure that information is provided in a timely 
manner and before the adoption of a resolution involving expenditure at the General 
Assembly and as required, with regard to potential programme budget implications 
arising from resolutions of the Main Committees or the plenary of the Assembly, 
including upon request by Member States before the issuance of oral statements on any 
negotiating text under consideration, as well as from initiatives discussed in subsidiary 
organs, in order to enable a fully informed decision-making process;

37. Recalls paragraph 49 of the report of the Advisory Committee,21 notes that 
a significant number of P-2 posts have been subject to reductions under the reform, 
and requests the Secretary-General to safeguard opportunities for early-career 
recruitment so as to ensure an open and accessible pathway for highly qualified young 
and junior professionals; 
 
38. Decides that staff members downsized as a result of the UN80 Initiative 
shall be screened for suitability for vacant posts and positions equally with other 
internal and external applicants; 
 
39. Recalls paragraph 56 of the report of the Advisory Committee, 22  and 
requests the Secretary-General to report on the implementation of the downsizing 
policy under the agenda item on human resources management, including its impact 
on staff composition; 
 
40. Encourages the Secretary-General to propose cost-saving proposals for 
post resources involving the abolishment and establishment of posts as a package 
within a budget section, where appropriate and if applicable; 
 
41. Requests the Secretary-General to continue to review how to effectively 
utilize remaining vacant posts and to report the results of the review by proposing 
either their retention with clear justification of need, the changing of posts or their 
abolishment, as appropriate, in his next proposed programme budget; 
 
42. Stresses the importance of using realistic and consistent vacancy rate 
assumptions when formulating post resources budget requests; 
 
43. Decides that the staffing table for 2026 shall be as set out in the annex to 
the present resolution; 
 
44. Also decides that a vacancy rate of 10.3 per cent for Professional staff and 
4.9 per cent for General Service staff shall be used as a basis for the calculation of 
the budget for 2026; 
 
45. Further decides to further reduce non-post resources under travel of staff 
by $3,800,000 United States dollars; 
 
46. Recalls paragraph 29 of its resolution 79/257 and decides to further reduce 
the recosting amount by $8,400,000; 
 
Part I 
Overall policymaking, direction and coordination 
 
Section 1 
Overall policymaking, direction and coordination 
 
 
47. Requests the Secretary-General to explore synergies among entities under 
section 1 to enhance efficiencies in the effective implementation of their specific 
mandates, and provide an update in the next proposed programme budget; 
 
48. Recalls paragraph I.5 of the report of the Advisory Committee, 23 and 
requests the Secretary-General to make every effort to avoid the proliferation of high-
level posts in the Organization by integrating functions arising from new and 
expanded mandates into existing positions, including through double-hatting 
arrangements, in close consultation with Member States;

49. 
Requests the Advisory Committee to include in its reports a concise summary 
of the budgetary impact and the financial implications of its recommendations; 
 
50. Recalls paragraphs 3 and 4 of section XVIII of its resolution 79/258 A on 
the decision to provide sufficient funding for the resident coordinator system, looks 
forward to receiving the refined comprehensive report at the eighty-first session, 
notes the need to align this process with the UN80 Initiative, and decides to authorize 
the Secretary-General, exceptionally and without creating a precedent, to enter into 
commitments with assessment not exceeding 53 million dollars for the period from 
1 January to 31 December 2026, in accordance with United Nations financial rules 
and regulations, to support the funding of the resident coordinator system and requests 
the Secretary-General to report on the use of the commitment authority in the context 
of the performance and budget reports; 
 
51. Decides against the establishment of the P-2 Associate Programme 
Management Officer in the Office for Digital and Emerging Technologies; 
 
52. Takes note of paragraph I.42 of the report of the Advisory Committee, 24 
and decides against the abolishment of the Chief Data Protection and Privacy Officer 
(D-1); 
 
Section 2 
General Assembly and Economic and Social Council affairs and 
conference management 
 
 
53. Recognizes the budgetary and operational factors influencing the provision 
of the interpretation and translation services provided by the Department for General 
Assembly and Conference Management, and encourages the Secretary-General to 
continue his efforts to address these challenges and engage with Member States and 
receive feedback on opportunities to enhance the quality and effectiveness of these 
services; 
 
54. Recalls paragraphs I.56, I.60 and I.61 of the report of the Advisory 
Committee, 25  decides to increase the workload standards by 20 per cent for all 
language staff, and requests the Secretary-General to report to the General Assembly 
in the context of future budget proposals; 
 
55. Decides not to abolish one post of Editorial and Desktop Publishing 
Assistant, Russian (G-5) (General Service (Other level)), in the Russian Text-
Processing Unit of the Russian Translation Service, Documentation Division, of the 
Department for General Assembly and Conference Management, New York (vacant); 
 
Part II 
Political affairs 
 
Section 3 
Political affairs 
 
 
56. Recalls its resolution 78/257, and reaffirms that the Peacebuilding Fund 
should be managed in accordance with the relevant provisions of the Financial 
Regulations and Rules of the United Nations; 
 
57. Decides against the abolishment of one encumbered P-3 post (Political 
affairs) (subprogramme 1, Prevention, management and resolution of conflicts); and 
one encumbered General Service post (subprogramme 3, Security Council affairs) 
(Social affairs);

59. Further decides not to abolish one D-1 post of Chief, Security Council

60. Decides not to abolish one P-3 Political Affairs Officer, Liaison Team, in

Disarmament 
 
 
61. Takes note of paragraph II.107 of the report of the Advisory Committee, 26

Section 5 
Peacekeeping operations 
 
 
62. Decides to maintain and redeploy the post of Assistant Secretary-General 
for Rule of Law and Security Institutions as the Assistant Secretary-General post in 
the Office for Mine Action and Police reporting directly to the Under-Secretary-
General for Peace Operations and responsible for overseeing the operations of the 
Police Division and the Mine Action Service and undertaking other functions for the 
Under-Secretary-General; 
 
Section 6 
Peaceful uses of outer space 
 
 
63. Takes note of paragraph II.172 of the report of the Advisory Committee, 27 
decides to abolish the P-2 Associate Scientific Affairs Officer, and further decides

International cooperation for development

66. Decides not to abolish one Economic Affairs Officer (P-5) in 
subprogramme 9; 
 
67. Also decides not to abolish the vacant P-4 Geospatial Information Officer 
in subprogramme 4 that supports the Committee of Experts on Global Geospatial

and decides to relocate the P-5 Senior Programme Management Officer from 
Washington, D.C., to Paris; 
 
Section 16 
International drug control, crime and terrorism prevention and criminal justice 
 
 
70. Recalls paragraph IV.135 of the report of the Advisory Committee, 30 and 
decides to abolish the Associate Crime Prevention and Criminal Justice Officer (P-2)

71. Decides against the abolishment of one D-1 Chief of Economic

73. Recalls paragraphs V.39 (j) and V.45 of the report of the Advisory 
Committee,31 and decides not to abolish one P-5 post of Senior Economic Affairs 
Officer, in the Subregional Office for North and Central Asia in Almaty, Kazakhstan; 
 
74. Decides not to approve the proposed abolishment of one P-3 post of

75. Decides not to abolish one Economic Affairs Officer (P-3) in 
subprogramme 11, Subregional activities in Central America, Cuba, the Dominican

Regular programme of technical cooperation 
 
 
77. Takes note of paragraphs 11 and 27 of the report of the Advisory 
Committee;32 
 
Part VII 
Global communications 
 
Section 28 
Global communications 
 
 
78. Recalls paragraph 62 of its resolution 79/257 and paragraph VII.4 of the 
report of the Advisory Committee,33 and requests the Secretary-General to complete 
the independent and impartial review of the Department of Global Communications 
by the end of 2026 without any further delay, reiterates that the review itself should 
be within existing resources and be aimed at achieving greater efficiency gains, and 
also requests the Secretary-General to provide the outcome of the review for the 
consideration of the General Assembly at the main part of its eighty-first session in 
the context of the proposed programme budget for 2027; 
 
79. Also recalls paragraph VII.10 of the report of the Advisory Committee, 34 
and looks forward to proposals on the restructuring of the Department of Global 
Communications, at both the Headquarters and regional levels, including United 
Nations information centres, in the next proposed programme budget; 
 
80. Takes note of paragraph VII.23 of the report of the Advisory Committee, 35 
and approves the proposed redeployment of posts to Vienna and Nairobi; 
 
81. Decides not to abolish one G-6, General Service (Other level) post of

Common support services 
 
Section 29A 
Department of Management Strategy, Policy and Compliance 
 
 
83. Recalls paragraph VIII.8 of the report of the Advisory Committee, 36 and 
further requests the Secretary-General to continue his efforts to provide adequate, 
accurate and timely supplementary information to the General Assembly in order to

84. Welcomes with appreciation the existing practice of informal sharing of 
consultants’ reports on management-related issues by the Secretary-General with 
Member States, and encourages the Secretary-General to continue this practice; 
 
85. Takes note of paragraphs VIII.20 and VIII.21 of the report of the Advisory 
Committee,37 and decides to approve the proposed redeployments to Bonn; 
 
Section 29B 
Department of Operational Support 
 
 
86. Recalls paragraph VIII.35 of the report of the Advisory Committee, 38 and 
requests the Secretary-General to propose further options to consolidate the 
Organization’s support functions, including through enhanced use of common 
administrative platforms, in his next budget report; 
 
87. Also recalls paragraph VIII.63 of the report of the Advisory Committee, 39 
and requests the Secretary-General to incorporate the views of client entities at the 
design stage of common administrative platforms and to conduct client-based 
performance assessments once implemented to ensure that common administrative 
platforms remain responsive, add value and are fit for purpose, and to report thereon 
to the General Assembly; 
 
88. Takes note of paragraph VIII.60 of the report of the Advisory Committee, 40 
decides against the abolishment of two D-1 posts at this time, and requests the 
Secretary General to review the necessity of these posts in the context of the proposed 
programme budget for 2028; 
 
Section 29C 
Office of Information and Communications Technology 
 
 
89. Recalls paragraphs VIII.7441 and VIII.9642 of the reports of the Advisory 
Committee, and requests the Secretary-General to enhance functional reporting 
between the information and communications technology Chiefs of United Nations 
entities and the Office of Information and Communications Technology, in a manner 
that complements and fully respects existing reporting mechanisms, and avoiding the 
creation of parallel or isolated structures, and update the General Assembly in the 
context of its next report on the information and communications technology strategy; 
 
90. Also recalls paragraph VIII.82 of the report of the Advisory Committee, 43 
reaffirms the importance of increasing transparency and clarity of information and 
communications technology expenditure, and therefore requests the Secretary-
General to provide consolidated information on information and communications 
technology budgets and expenditures, including the intention to utilize information 
and communications technology resources more efficiently, to the General Assembly 
during its next session;

Committee,44 reiterates the need for a holistic vision for the future use of data centres

provide information on possible consolidation measures for existing data centres and 
the potential cost-efficiencies available in the proposed programme budget for 2027; 
 
Section 29D 
Administration, Nairobi

Support services; 
 
Part X 
Jointly financed administrative activities and special expenses 
 
Section 32 
Special expenses 
 
 
93. 
Decides to authorize a commitment authority without assessment on 
Member States in an amount not exceeding 52,611,600 dollars under section 32, Special 
expenses, to support one-time costs in 2026, which enables the implementation of post 
abolishments and post relocations, including for special political missions, and all the 
temporary posts proposed by the Secretary-General for transitional capacities; 
 
94. 
Requests the Secretary-General to keep to an absolute minimum the amount 
required from the one-time commitment authority, and emphasizes that the commitment 
authority shall not require any additional assessments from Member States; 
 
Part XI 
Capital expenditures 
 
Section 33 
Construction, alteration, improvement and major maintenance

1,247,400 dollars; 
 
96. Also decides to reduce resources for Headquarters by 4,102,100 dollars; 
 
Part XII 
Safety and security 
 
Section 34

paragraphs.1: Reaffirms rule 153 of its rules of procedure;
paragraphs.2: Also reaffirms the Regulations and Rules Governing Programme Planning, the Programme Aspects of the Budget, the Monitoring of Implementation and the Methods of Evaluation;10
paragraphs.3: Further reaffirms the Financial Regulations and Rules of the United Nations;11
paragraphs.5: Endorses the conclusions and recommendations contained in the reports of the Advisory Committee of Administrative and Budgetary Questions, subject to the provisions of the present resolution;
paragraphs.6: Reaffirms that the Fifth Committee is the appropriate Main Committee of the General Assembly entrusted with responsibilities for administrative and budgetary matters, and reaffirms the role of the Fifth Committee in carrying out a thorough analysis and approving human and financial resources and policies, with a view to ensuring full, effective and efficient implementation of all mandated programmes and activities and the implementation of policies in this regard;
paragraphs.7: Stresses that finance serves as a foundation of and an important element underpinning United Nations governance;
paragraphs.8: Recalls its resolution 79/318 of 18 July 2025 on the UN80 Initiative, and welcomes the efforts of the Secretary-General to strengthen the United Nations through structural and programmatic realignment to address duplication, reduce overlap, enhance transparency, strengthen mandate delivery and make the Organization more efficient, effective, impactful and fit for purpose for the people it serves;
paragraphs.9: Notes the interconnected nature of the three workstreams of the UN80 Initiative, which seek operational efficiencies and improvements, review of mandate implementation and structural and programmatic realignment of the Organization, stresses in this regard the importance of ensuring close coordination and coherence among the three workstreams so that their outcomes continue to be ambitious and mutually reinforcing and contribute to a comprehensive, accountable, transparent and __________________ 4 A/80/112. 5 A/80/153. 6 A/80/90 and A/80/90/Add.1. 7 Official Records of the General Assembly, Eightieth Session, Supplement No. 7 (A/80/7) and A/80/7/Add.9, A/80/7/Add.2 and A/80/7/Add.3. 8 A/80/264, on budgeting in organizations of the United Nations system, and A/80/263, on the review of the implementation of the principle of mutual recognition within the United Nations system. 9 A/80/264/Add.1 and A/80/263/Add.1. 10 ST/SGB/2018/3. 11 ST/SGB/2013/4 and ST/SGB/2013/4/Amend.1. A/C.5/80/L.4 3/14 25-21160 integrated reform process, and looks forward to tangible outcomes and proposals presented to Member States in 2026 and 2027;
paragraphs.10: Recalls paragraphs 4, 6 and 16 of the report of the Advisory Committee, 12 stresses that the UN80 Initiative requires going beyond a one-time reform exercise to also incorporate continuous efforts to ensure long-term effective and efficient mandate delivery across all three pillars of the work of the United Nations, and requests the Secretary-General to pursue synergies to achieve greater efficiency in the management of resources and to report on the outcome of such efforts in his next budget submission;
paragraphs.11: Requests the Secretary-General to continue to follow the legislative framework, as agreed by Member States, and the established procedural steps applicable to proposals presented as part of the UN80 Initiative;
paragraphs.12: Recognizes the need for indicators for providing quantifiable information on entities’ efforts to drive a culture of efficiency and cost-effectiveness, and requests the Secretary-General to include, in future proposed programme budgets, quantitative indicators on entities’ cost efficiency measures and an analysis of their effectiveness;
paragraphs.13: Also recognizes the need to analyse the impact, costs and benefits of the Secretary-General’s reform efforts, and requests the Secretary-General to include, in his future proposed programme budgets, the impact of changes on mandate implementation and performance;
paragraphs.14: Recalls paragraph 28 of its resolution 79/257, and requests the Secretary- General to continue applying zero-based budgeting in order to end the high degree of automaticity in future budget preparation and match the proposed requirements with programmes whose mandates are still valid;
paragraphs.15: Requests the Secretary-General to maintain the momentum of the UN80 Initiative, continue to identify efficiencies in how each Secretariat entity can enhance the overall effectiveness of the Organization and strengthen budget discipline, by absorbing the resource implications of new mandates within existing resources, where appropriate;
paragraphs.16: Recalls paragraph 44 of the report of the Advisory Committee, 13 emphasizes the importance of the rejuvenation of the Secretariat, requests the Secretary-General to include proposals for programmatic realignments and structural changes, including with the aim to reduce or reclassify the overall number of Under- Secretary-General, Assistant Secretary-General, D-2 and D-1 posts markedly in the context of the UN80 Initiative, in the proposed programme budget for 2028;
paragraphs.17: Also recalls paragraph 29 of the report of the Advisory Committee, 14 reaffirms paragraphs 19 and 64 of its resolution 79/257, stresses that the implementation of the UN80 Initiative should be supported by a coordinated approach to organizational transformation across the various entities of the Organization, and underscores that internal control and accountability are central principles of management reform, and the importance of strengthening a culture of accountability through the relevant internal oversight and control mechanisms to ensure effective, accountable and transparent delivery of reforms;
paragraphs.18: Requests the Secretary-General to ensure effective and efficient utilization of available existing resources and programme delivery by senior managers and programme managers, including through clearly defined results-based performance indicators and benchmarks that provide feedback to senior managers and programme managers and drive improvements on the delivery of mandates; __________________ 12 A/80/7/Add.9. 13 Ibid. 14 Ibid. A/C.5/80/L.4 25-21160 4/14
paragraphs.19: Recalls paragraph 74 of the report of the Advisory Committee,15 encourages continued work on improving administrative and operational effectiveness of the Secretariat, including in coordination with other United Nations system entities, and looks forward to receiving proposals on restructuring Secretariat operations;
paragraphs.20: Welcomes the Secretary-General’s proposals on the consolidation and streamlining of support services and structures across the Secretariat, encourages the implementation of such measures to achieve both immediate and long-term financial savings and to foster a more integrated flexible and resilient approach to service delivery, and looks forward to additional proposals from the next phase of work on the proposed programme budget for 2027, while taking into account the different sizes, complexities and operational environments of Secretariat entities;
paragraphs.21: Recalls paragraph 71 of the report of the Advisory Committee,16 and requests the Secretary-General to operate under a common approach to scalability for transactional services, including those provided under common administrative platforms, that aligns service demand and related staffing requirements with workload indicators, including variables related to productivity and differences in funding sources;
paragraphs.22: Requests the Secretary-General to continue his efforts to achieve transparency and improve the accuracy, comprehensiveness and analysability of the budgetary data, refine the presentation of the proposed programme budget, and to provide complete, clear, comparable and transparent financial data to the General Assembly, including both gross and net requirements, and preliminary cost estimates that are available for the respective year at the time of publication of the proposed programme budget, such as, inter alia, total construction and total recosting estimates, so as to give clarity on the real growth of the budget request to enable Member States to make well-informed decisions;
paragraphs.23: Recalls paragraph 23 of its resolution 79/257, and requests the Secretary- General to continue his efforts to provide accurate, adequate and dynamic information related to administrative, budgetary and human resources matters to Member States through the Umoja portal and to continue to enhance Member States’ access to the Umoja system;
paragraphs.24: Requests the Secretary-General to update the search and retrieval tools within the e-deleGATE platform to enable Member States to search using keywords across documents and enhance efforts to preserve institutional knowledge;
paragraphs.25: Also requests the Secretary-General to consider and implement options to improve the ease of access to e-deleGATE through multi-factor authentication for delegates;
paragraphs.26: Recalls paragraph 80 of the report of the Advisory Committee,17 notes that proposals for relocations should ensure better and more integrated mandate delivery across all aspects of the Organization’s work and contribute to its strategic objectives, while eliminating duplication and saving costs, and emphasizes that all current and future relocation proposals shall be based on functional assessments, including proximity to operations and field presence, demonstrating where work can be delivered most cost-efficiently, and that these assessments shall be provided to Member States;

paragraphs.29: Recalls paragraph I.70 of the report of the Advisory Committee, 20 notes current challenges in ensuring full and uninterrupted conference management because of the liquidity situation of the Organization, and encourages the Secretary-General to make additional efforts to provide conference management to meetings contained in the calendar of conferences of the United Nations for 2026 and approved by the General Assembly;
